loans.name: Badamsuren

texts.en: Badamsuren is 27 years old and lives with his parents and siblings in Khovd province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger". His mother has a monthly pension of 81,000 tugrugs (~560 USD). Because of his low income, Badamsuren is operating a transportation service in order to help with the family's living expenses. He transports baggage and luggage to and from the countryside to the center of the province. Besides transportation he also sells coal and firewood by using his truck. Badamsuren started his business in 2006 after buying a big truck of his own. He has found success with his business over the years and has built a reputation as a good and honest driver. Badamsuren is focused on continuing to improve his business and provide a good life for his family. He hopes to use his earnings to buy a new truck in the near future. Badamsuren is requesting a 3,300,000 tugrug (~2300 USD) loan to purchase machinery parts for his truck and some coal to sell.

loans.use: to purchase machinery parts for his truck and some coal

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma T. is from the village of Alindahaw, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 59 years old. Norma is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Norma runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Norma has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos a month from these activities.

In 2008, Norma joined GDMPC, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Norma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Norma is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be the third loan taken out by Norma from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Riza

texts.en:
Riza E. is from the village of San Carlos, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 19 years old and is single. Riza owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling daily-use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Riza joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Riza is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding her business. This loan will be her fifth from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Sherali

texts.en: K. Sherali, age 51, is a cattle breeder and the responsible father of five children, who has always watched over his family’s financial security. He accomplishes this by caring for his animals on a daily basis. He clearly remembers the time when he decided to become independent, with a small number of animals and a small patch of land. Sherali has more than fifteen years of experience. Cattle-breeding is the main source of income for his family and generates the necessary income allowing Sherali to support his family and improve their living conditions. Now he has applied for a loan of 2,000 USD, which he is planning to use to purchase cattle. More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty. IMON's History Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cattle to expand his business

loans.name: Begidjon

texts.en: K. Begidjon is from a natural born agricultural family. With immense strength of character, she has observed that only labor with much dedication rewards with good vegetables. With this conception, she has worked her lands, cultivating products native to the region such as potatoes and corn, among others. Begidjon is a widow and the mother of one child. She feels more responsibility to continue with her daily labor. Some time ago she acquired a small quantity of small animals to satisfy the hunger of her family in an epoch of shortage. In return, while watching her cultivated lands, she leaves the little animals free so that they can locate their daily sustenance. Begidjon seeks a loan of 3,000 Somoni to invest in seeds and mineral fertilizer to improve the quality of her produce. Let's support this brave mother who has respectable goals to improve her living condition for the sake of the dearest person in her life – her daughter. loans.use: To purchase seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Matt

texts.en:
Mr. Matt S. is a villager in Trapaing Leuk village in Takoe province, Cambodia. He is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to cultivate rice to earn his living. His wife, Mrs. Mit Sam, helps him with the farming.

Matt is the father of two children. One attends the local school and the younger one is too young to work or study because this child is 3 years old. His wife and daughter are presented in the photo with him.

Matt now has a problem because he does not have enough money to buy more fertilizers to support his field. Matt decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and he will use the rest of the loan to buy a water machine to water his crop.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and a water machine to water his crop.

loans.name: Mahmadi

texts.en: S. Mahmadi is 45 years old and is married with four children. He manufactures by order the carved wooden doors, window frames and partitions of the national oriental style. He has been in this business for ten years already and, during these years, he has become a real expert in his business and has a lot of clients. Since Mahmadi has a lot of clients and demand, the business is very successful and brings in a stable and significant income, allowing Mahmadi to improve the living conditions of his family. Now he has a great order for manufacturing window frames and doors. Thus today Mahmadi requests 10,000 Somoni to purchase input materials of wood products for his business. Mahmadi’s previous loan was managed by him without violations, and he promises to repay the current one on time. He is counting on your help and he expresses his gratitude to everyone for supporting him. loans.use: To purchase input materials for his business

loans.name: Leizel

texts.en: Leizel C. is from the village of Biasong. She is 29 years old and is married. Leizel owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She is just starting this business. In 2009, Leizel joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her first from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Son

texts.en:
Mrs. Son T. is a villager in Pour Village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice. In this farming activity she faces an obstacle so she decided to ask for a loan to buy more fertilizers to support the field to make her crop more productive.

Mrs. Son T. is a widow with two children who all live with her. She also has four grandchildren, three of whom are attending the local school while the youngest one is too young to work or study because this child is only five years old.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer to support her rice field

loans.name: Nurali

texts.en: Nurali T. is 40 years old. He is married with five children. From the time he was young, Nurali learned to work in small business with his parents. With a lot of sacrifice, he became a main producer in agriculture in the area where he lives. After he married, he continued working in the same business, watching the business grow as a result of his sacrifice and seeing his family progressing more and more. With that income, Nurali was able to open a dispensary in his house and also raise cattle successfully. His hope is to continue growing and improving his business to offer a better future for his children and see them as professional, ethical and hardworking. For this reason he is asking for a loan of $800. He wants this loan to buy livestock, as raising and selling the animals generates an excellent profit margin. Be an important part of the growth of Nurali’s business. loans.use: Purchasing cattle to expand the business

loans.name: Khanifa

texts.en: I. Khanifa works selling clothing from her own stall inside the clothing market in the beautiful town of Isfara, Tajikistan. She has spent the last five years dedicating herself to this business. lMON has provided Khanifa with financial help for the last two years and with a total of four loans which have allowed her to increase her stock and ensure her three children’s maintenance, thanks to the business which generates enough income in order to be able to live with dignity. Khanifa currently has a pressing need to acquire more clothing for the winter season and for this reason she came to IMON looking for more support. Her goal is to continue expanding and improving her business every day. Considering that her husband has no fixed job, Khanifa has to work hard in order to improve their living standard. Khanifa is very grateful to everyone who is helping her. loans.use: To purchase winter clothing for her business

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en:
K. Yusuf is 46 years old, has a secondary technical education, and is married with three children. He lives in the town of Kanibadam, Tajikistan.

Yusuf has a grocery store and has been in this business for five years. He plans to use the loan to increase his product selection. His store is located ten kilometers away from the center of the region and is one of only two stores in the village that sell food products to local residents.

Because the stores in the center of the region close early, residents returning from work cannot always purchase necessary food items. Yusuf’s store takes into account the needs of the clients and is open until late evening, giving residents the opportunity to purchase necessary products.

On the eve of the New Year Yusuf plans to restock his products to meet all the needs of his clients. Be an important part of the growth of Yusuf’s business.

loans.use: To increase the range of his goods

loans.name: Mrs. Savet Nou Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This is a group loan to 21 people who all live in Dak Por village in Takeo province.  The loan is coordinated through the village bank. All the members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes. 

Mrs. Savet N. is the village bank president.  She is a farmer and owns 0.5 hectares on which she grows rice. Her husband, Mr. Y. Phal, is a construction worker who makes a small income to support the family. Although Mrs. Savet N. and her husband both work hard they still do not earn enough to fix up their house and make it livable.  In order to repair her house, Mrs. Savet N. is asking for a loan.  Mrs. Savet N. has three children, two of whom are in school and the third is a silk weaver.

loans.use: House repairs to make a livable home

loans.name: Mrs. Chhang Vanna Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank consists of 16 people who live in Dak Por village in Takeo province. All the members will use the loan that they have obtained for different purposes. Mrs. C. Vanna is the village bank president who has been selected by the members. She is a farmer who owns a small field on which she cultivates rice for a living. Her husband, Mr. Bil Chantha, is a construction worker who can earn a small income to support the family. Although they try to work hard, they still do not earn enough income to support the family, so Mrs. C. Vanna decided to ask for a loan to buy more rice to keep in stock to resell at a better price. Mrs. C. Vanna is a mother of five children, one of whom is a garment worker, while three of the others are attending the local school and the youngest one, at the age of five, is too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more rice to keep in stock to resell at a better price

loans.name: Djamela

texts.en: Djamela K. is 52 years old. She is divorced and has three adult children. Djamela has a grocery store where she sells foodstuffs of different types and tastes. She has been in this business for 14 years. The inventory she has for sale is of very good quality and selection. Djamela is respectful and patient with all of her customers, which attracts people and brings them back to her vending facility to buy groceries again. Djamela is seeking to keep her business sustainable and has requested a loan of 5,000 Somoni to increase the inventory she has for sale. One of her dreams is that her children progress by means of their studies. We believe this current loan will enhance the potential of her business and help Djamela reach all of her aspirations. loans.use: Increasing stock of food to sell

loans.name: Baasanjav

texts.en: Baasanjav is 45 years old and lives with his wife and two children in Hovd province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a Mongolian traditional tent called  a "ger." His children, aged 12 and 16, both attend a local secondary school. Baasanjav operates a taxi service as well as a coal selling business in his town. He transports people to and from the center of the province and Ulaanbaatar city, the largest and most crowded city in the country, which is the capital of Mongolia. In his free time he transports the coal he sells. Baasanjav is a very hardworking person and is known for his good personality. He has worked hard over the years to grow his businesses and stabilize his income. He has used his earnings to support his family and improve their quality of life. He says, "I want my children to be educated so they will become good and happy people." He is requesting a 250,000-tugrug loan to purchase a great amount of coal to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a great amount of coal

loans.name: Chuluuntsetseg

texts.en: Chuluuntsetseg is a 35-year-old single mother who lives with her ten-year-old son in Zavkhan province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her son is a secondary school student. Chuluuntsetseg operates a small bakery in her town. She makes a variety of breads and buns that are very popular among her many customers. Chuluuntsetseg started her bakery business in 2003 with only one stove at her home. At first she had only a manual oven to make her products but, after several years of steady earnings, she was able to purchase a more efficient modern oven last year. Her success has also enabled her to hire seven more assistants at her bakery booth. Chuluuntsetseg is working hard to continue her success in the future. She hopes to soon purchase more tools and supplies to help her business and says, "My goal is to one day own my own workplace." She is requesting a 2,000,000-tugrug loan to purchase tools and flour for her bakery.

loans.use: To purchase tools and flour for her bakery

loans.name: Tsend-Ayush

texts.en:
Tsend-Ayush is a 45-year-old single mother who lives with her two children in Hovd province, Mongolia. They live together in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her two children, a son and a daughter, both attend a local secondary school.

Tsend-Ayush operates a consumer goods trading business out of a shipping container at a local market. She sells a variety of household items to the residents of her neighborhood. She started her business in 2005 after managing a second-hand goods trading business for several years. She has since grown her business into a stable operation and has found success operating near her home.

For the future, Tsend-Ayush hopes to save enough money for her children's education. She is a very hardworking woman and attributes her success to her good accounting skills. She is focused on the future and says, “I want to provide my children with a happy life.”

Tsend-Ayush is requesting a 2,160,000 tugrug loan to purchase goods to sell in her business.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to sell

loans.name: Otgondemberel

texts.en:
Otgondemberel is 41 years old and lives with his wife and four children in the Zavkhan province in western Mongolia. He and his family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger." His oldest daughter and his son are in university and his youngest two daughters go to a local secondary school.

He currently operates a metal-product-making business in his town with the help of his wife. They produce a variety of traditional Mongolian household goods, such as fire scissors and fire pots (large cooking and serving pots). Their products are very popular among their many customers due to their good quality and unique style.

Otgondemberel started his business in 2000 and has built a successful operation over the years. His products display traditional Mongolian customs, which are popular with the people of his province. His earnings have enabled him to make improvements to his home, providing a more comfortable life for his family. 

Otgondemberel is focused on the future and has many new ideas for his business. He hopes to expand his product line in the near future and begin making souvenirs. He says, "All I want is to save enough money for my children's education." 

Otgondemberel is requesting a 2,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase metals and iron for his business and for his youngest daughter's treatment as she was recently diagnosed as having cancer.

loans.use: To purchase metals and iron for his business and for his youngest daughter's cancer treatment

loans.name: Toilat

texts.en:
Toilat is 32 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in Bayan-Ulgii province, Mongolia. He and his family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger". Both his sons attend a local secondary school. 

Toilat has operated a taxi service in his town since 2005. He drives people around his town and throughout Bayan-Uulgii province. Before he started a taxi service, Toilat ran a grocery store with his wife.  With the income from the grocery store he bought a car. Now his wife runs the grocery store while he provides a taxi service for the residents of his province.  

Toilat is very hardworking and is known for his good character. He has gained a lot of experience over the years and is a trusted driver for his many customers. He works hard to maintain his success and is hopeful about the future. He is requesting a 200,000 tugrug loan to purchase new tires for his car.

loans.use: To purchase 4 tires

loans.name: Tsienhorol

texts.en: Tsienhorol is 40 years old and lives with her husband and three sons in Zavkhan province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. All her three sons attend a local secondary school. Her husband operates a transportation service as well as a coal trading business in order to improve their quality of life. Tsienhorol, herself, operates a small grocery shop in her town with some help from her husband. She started her grocery shop in 2008 after conducting a consumer goods trading business for a while. Tsienhorol has found success with her new business and due to her good management has doubled her profits in just two years. Tsienhorol is focused on continuing her success in the future and says, "It is hard to live in Mongolia if you don't conduct your own business. Our shop is the big source of income for my family, so my dream is to continue to grow my business in the future." Tsienhorol is requesting a 700,000-tugrug loan to purchase grocery items for her shop.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for her shop

loans.name: Tungalag

texts.en: Tungalag is 41 years old and lives with her husband and three children in Zavhan province in western Mongolia. She and her family live in a traditional Mongolian housing tent called a "ger." Her eldest daughter, Altanhuu, is in university and her younger two sons go to a local secondary school. Her husband operates a firewood trading business to supplement their earnings. She currently operates a shoe making business in her town. She produces a variety of traditional Mongolian shoes. Her products are very popular among their many customers due to their good quality and unique style. Tungalag started her business in 2000 after working as a shoe maker in a state factory for several years. Her products display traditional Mongolian customs that are popular with the people of this province. Tungalag is focused on the future and has many new ideas for her business. She hopes to expand her business in the future. She says, "All I want is to save enough money for my children's education." Tungalag is requesting a 1,000,000-tugrug loan to purchase fabrics and raw materials for her shoe making business.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and raw materials

loans.name: Dulambayar

texts.en: Dulambayar is 43 years old and lives with her husband and three sons in Khovd province, Mongolia. Her husband is handicapped. All of her three sons (aged 7, 13, and 17), attend a local secondary school. Dulambayar operates a grocery and vegetable trading business in her town. She grows all the vegetables that she sells at her booth.  Dulambayar started her business in 1994 by planting variety of vegetables and has built a stable operation over the years. She is a very hardworking businesswoman and is focused on the future. Her business has provided her family with financial stablilty and has enabled her to improve her quality of life. Dulambayar has many plans for the future and says, "With continued success, I hope to buy more fields to plant my vegetables." She is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~700 USD) loan to purchase more products to sell in her business.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of food products.

loans.name: Ulziijargal

texts.en: Ulziijargal is 50 years old and lives with her husband and four children in the Zavkhan province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Her children, aged 18, 20, and 25, attend a university. Ulziijargal owns a dairy product retail business that she operates at the local market in her town. She began her business in 2007 and, since then, she has stabilized her business and has earned many loyal customers. The winter months are important for dairy retailers, as it is the time when the price of milk goes up. Ulziijargal is requesting a loan for 500,000 tugrugs (~350 USD) in order to purchase a large amount of dairy products from the countryside. She can prepare for the price increase by purchasing the products now, and she will earn more profit.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of dairy products.

loans.name: Saiyohat

texts.en:
M. Saiyohat is 45 years old. She is married and has three children. Saiyohat is a market vendor. She sells fodder for the animals. With the income, she purchases small bulls for raising and further selling. Saiyohat is applying for a loan in the amount of 5000 Somoni. She is planning to increase her working capital to expand the business. She will use the generated income for forming a private farm for breeding the cattle. Saiyohat thanks all supporting her and promises to repay the loan promptly. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Increasing working capital in order to expand the business.

loans.name: Gulnafisa

texts.en:
R. Gulnafisa is 23 years old. She is running her own business. For 5 years she has been working in a beauty salon. In the salon she provides the various services of hair styling, haircutting, manicures, and cosmetologist. Her business is successful and generates the stable income for her family. Now Gulnafisa is planning to purchase cosmetics and other accessories for her beauty salon. With this purpose, she requests 4500 Somoni. Gulnafisa thanks all supporting her and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: To buy felt and sewing supplies.

loans.name: Abdusharif

texts.en: Abdusharif is a hardworking and responsible married father of three. He works for a business, but he felt the need to earn extra income to cover all the family expenses and pay for his children's education. So, 11 years ago, Abdusharif started processing and selling dried apricots. The demand for his products increased and he gained many more customers. To cover all of his customers' orders, he is asking for a loan of US$1,500 to buy the food supplies he needs to continue growing his business. Abdusharif is making the effort to move his business and his family forward but he needs your help to do it. loans.name: Ehsonjon

texts.en: Ehsonjon is a hardworking, responsible man who lives with his wife and two children. In order to provide for his children's needs while caring for them, he decided to start his own business processing and selling dried apricots. His wife helped him by sharing her best recipes and processing secrets. Fortunately, his work has paid off, and his business has grown with more orders and new clients coming in every day. Ehsonjon is asking for a loan of US$1,500, which he will use to purchase needed supplies and to remodel his location. He hopes that by doing this he will increase his sales and income. You can be a part of this growth. Ehsonjon and his parents thank you for your generosity and kindness. loans.name: Analyn L.

texts.en:
Analyn L. M. is from the village of Napurog, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 22 years old. Analyn L. is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Analyn L. owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of products in the local community. Analyn L. has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month through the business.

In 2088, Analyn L. joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Analyn L. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Analyn L. is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Analyn L. from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital

loans.name: Khanga Group

texts.en:
Jambo from Dar es Salaam, Tanzania!
Meet Bakari M., a 34-year-old newspaper salesman and stationery shop owner. He is married and has two daughters, ages six and three. He also cares for his two younger sisters, who are 15 and 20, and their mother, who stays with them.
Bakari has been running his business since 2006. The shop is open from 8 a.m. until 6 p.m. daily. He makes about 20,000 Tanzanian shillings a day, which is about US$15, giving him a monthly profit of about US$450. He plans to use this loan to buy school books for children, which are commonly sold in stationery shops like his along with notebooks, greeting cards, paper, pens, and sometimes even candies.
This is Bakari's first loan from a microfinance institution! He is grateful for your support. In the photo, Bakari is the first on the left, wearing a red shirt. He is pictured with the other members of his loan group, which named itself Khanga. The group members will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan. This loan is what Tujijenge calls a "Motisha Loan." It is for borrowers who have excellent repayment histories and wish to take out a larger loan than the original amount before their first loan term has ended. Thank you for supporting these successful microfinance clients!

loans.use: To buy school books and stationery items to sell in his shop

To make a living, Sandra owns and operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Sandra has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month through the business.

In 2008, Sandra joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Sandra has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Sandra is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Sandra from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house. loans.name: Eriyah

texts.en: Eriyah O. O. is thirty-two years old, single and has no children. His business is located at Ongata Rongai in Nairobi near a bus stop where there is a very good flow of customers. His business is well known by the name Exodus Carpentry. He makes furniture that he has been selling to the local people for the last three years. He has two employees who work closely with him and he hopes that he will create more jobs in the future. Eriyah has to manage insecurity to safeguard his business. He also needs a larger space to compete in a market that has many people doing the same business as his. He is using his loan to buy timber to grow his business, open an outlet at Kiserian and supply his products to the supermarkets. He is hardworking, God fearing and has big dreams for his future.

loans.use: To buy timber

To make a living, Ginalyn owns and operates a fishing business, catching and selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Ginalyn has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month through the business.

In 2008, Ginalyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ginalyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fish to sell. Ginalyn is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase a fishing boat. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Ginalyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. loans.name: Virgincita

texts.en: Mrs. Virgincita B., 44 years of age, is married and is a resident of Sumirap, Tangub City. They are blessed with nine children of whom four are still studying and the rest are now working. Her husband is doing manual labor jobs and at the same time is engaged in farming. With this situation, it has been so hard for her to raise their big family. She decided to engage in fish selling and was able to sustain this business for three years, even in times of hardships. She joined Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) a year ago because she is very much interested in PMPC's various products and services. Having successfully repaid two previous loans, she was able to borrow an amount of 7,000 Philippine pesos for her third loan to obtain needed capital for her business. Her dream in life is to be able to send all her children to college so that they will have a better future and be able to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: Additional capital for fish selling business

loans.name: Hannah Mae

texts.en:
Hannah Mae J. is from the village of Taboo, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 21 years old. Hannah Mae is single. To make a living, Hannah Mae sells rice in the local community. 

In 2008, Hannah Mae joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Hannah Mae has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and to provide working capital. Hannah Mae is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used for house repairs. This will be the second loan taken out by Hannah Mae from PMPC. She plans to pay for her loan using the proceeds from her rice-selling business, which sees seasonal profits.

loans.name: Engelina

texts.en: Mrs. Engelina M., 30 years old, is married and is a resident of Sumirap, Tangub City. She operates a sari-sari store (local convenience store). With the support of her husband, who is a carpenter and mason, she was able to open this little business three years ago. She is able to make at least 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month through the business. This income is so helpful to support her family, which includes four children of whom three are now of school age. She joined Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) a year ago because she is very interested in PMPC's products and services. For her third loan, she was given the privilege to borrow an amount of 8,000 PHP to provide capital for her existing sari-sari store. The future income from this loan will be used for the family's daily basic needs and for her weekly repayments in the cooperative. She is also making extra savings for her children’s future needs, especially for their education.

loans.use: Additional capital for her sari-sari store

texts.en: Nefisa Lasi K. is currently in the business of selling charcoal from her home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. Nefisa is 40 years old and is a widow. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Abd Al Azez

texts.en:
Growing grape vines!

Abd Al Azez M. is a young Palestinian man aged 29 years old. He is married with three young children aged 4, 3 and 1 year old.

Abd al Azez is an employee of the Palestinian National Authority. In addition to this job he owns land where he grows grape vines and sell his grapes in the market or to juice factories. Qabatia where Abdl Azez and his family live is famous for its delicious grapes and fertile soil.

As Mr. M. enjoys taking care of grapes, he would like to buy an additional piece of land and buy new seedlings. So he requested a loan of 2,500 USD from FATEN to expand his project as it’s successful and the expansion would positively impact his family’s income

Abd Al-Azez appears in the photo next to his lovely grape vines.

loans.use: To buy an additional piece of land on which to grow more grape vines

loans.name: Khitam

texts.en:
Khitam G., runs a ladies’ and kids’ clothing store. Due to its success, Khitam is applying for a loan from FATEN in order to open another store in another location in Jaba’ village, Jineen district, and to buy more clothes. This will increase the number of her customers by having a variety of products that meets all tastes.

Khitam has a strong, independent and ambitious character and has had good experience in the field of selling clothes for more than 5 years.

Khitam is a wife and the mother of five children: two girls and three boys who are school students. Her husband works in a restaurant in Israel.

Khitam appears at her store in the photo.

loans.use: To open another store and to buy goods

loans.name: Mahmood

texts.en:
Mahmood S. is a young man, 25 years old. His family consists of four brothers and one sister in addition to his mother. He lives with his family at Deir Al Ghosoun, a village of Tulkarem District. He shares the responsibility of supporting the family with one of his brothers who works for the Palestinian National Authority.

Mahmood is in the process of preparing his land for growing plants in addition to installing more greenhouses. He is applying for a loan from FATEN to increase his income by growing more plants and by installing a number of additional greenhouses.

This project will help Mahmood ensure better living conditions for his family and enable him to collect enough money to get married soon and start his own family.

Mahmood appears in the photo at his greenhouse surrounded by lovely cucumber plants.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Mrs. Josephine S., 45 years of age, is a sari-sari (general) store owner and a gasoline retailer.  She is married, but separated, and a resident of Maquilao, Tangub City. She is blessed with three children, two of whom are still dependent minors.  She is also receiving support from her common-law husband who is a fisherman. To help support their family needs, she began a sari-sari store and for five years she has been able to maintain her business. She joined Kiva partner PAGLAUM MPC two years ago because she was very much interested in PMPC's wide product offerings. With her good credit record, she was given the privilege to apply for a loan of 5,000 PHP as her fifth loan to allow her to add to the capital of her sari-sari store and gasoline retailing business. The future income from this business will be used for their daily basic needs and savings.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose Q. K. is in the business of brewing and selling local alcoholic beverages. She is requesting a loan to purchase more materials to use. Rose is 30 years-old and divorced with four children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To purchase materials.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth M. M. is twenty-six years-old, unmarried and has a nine month old baby boy. Her business is located in Pipeline, a busy place in Nairobi and is called Furaha cereals. She used to sell telephone air time but then changed to selling cereals and vegetables. She serves local restaurants and other people in the area. She plans to use her loan to buy more cereals and she sees herself supplying wholesale in the future. Her major challenges are insufficient funds, harassment by local authorities and lack of permanent customers. In the future, she hopes to purchase a plot of land and build her own home. She is honest, hardworking, disciplined and social.

loans.use: To purchase beans, green lentils and rice.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda Barnidas is a 65-year-old mother of eight children whose ages range from 23 to 44 years-old. Through her hard work and determination in running a business to help her husband support the education of their children until they graduated from college, all the children are now professionals. However, Erlinda is not free of her financial obligations to her children because they have their own families to take care of. Therefore, she joined Kiva partner ASHI to have access to credit which she will use to grow a business which she has been nurturing for a long time. With the help of her farmer husband, Erlinda plans to purchase additional cattle which she will raise with her existing cattle in her selling and breeding business. Through ASHI she is requesting a loan and Erlinda has the courage to invest the loan in her business because she has much experience in this field. She knows that once the cattle are sold, profits can as much as double from the initial investment. She negotiates, supported by her husband, with potential buyers in different municipalities during market days. On these days, people from different municipalities also come to buy other commodities being sold.

Erlinda’s intention of making her business successful is not only for herself but for her grandchildren as well. She wants to make her grandchildren happy by supporting their financial needs if their parents have problems to do so.

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Hani

texts.en:
Hani S. is a young Palestinian man, 25 years old. He works as a police officer in the Palestinain National Authority.

In addittion to his job, as his monthly salary is not enough to cover his expenses, he owns a small grocery store in his village. At this store he sells, canned food, candy, vegetables, gas cooking canisters, children toys, etc. He appears in the photo at his store.

Hani requested 1,000 USD from FATEN to buy some extra goods for his shop to increase his income.

Hani is still single and lives with his family. He hopes to save some money to build his own house and start his own family.

loans.use: To purchase new goods and products for his grocery store

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda G. is so happy to have reached the age of 47. Despite poverty, she has been able to raise her six children, whose ages are now from five to 20 years old. Her husband is very supportive and loving towards her and that is why she became so eager to work harder to achieve her dreams for her children and for changing her family's standard of living.

When she became a member of ASHI, she started her own business of doing manicures and pedicures to help her husband with another source of income. All throughout the loans she received from ASHI since she became a member, there was never a time that she had a problem in repayment because she knows how to budget her finances for the business and family.

During harvest, some of the profit from her rice selling was saved and some was reinvested in the business along with the loan she requested to grow her business further. Her daily income out of her manicure/pedicure business is used to pay her weekly amortization in ASHI. Most of the time her profits are less than the expenses, so the loans Rosalinda takes from ASHI are a great source to reinforce her capital.

Now that Rosalinda’s children are at a higher education level, they need a larger amount of money for their educational expenses. Therefore, with her and her husband’s broad experience in running their rice planting business, she would like to grow it further.  However, she needed a larger amount of capital. To address her problem, she would like to request a loan from ASHI. Rosalinda also hopes that she will have a good harvest and favorable profits so her younger children can graduate from college, unlike her eldest who is now 20 years old.

loans.use: To purchase necessary supplies in preparation for rice planting.

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda C. lives in the biggest Barangay (village) of San Jose De Buenavista, province of Antique. The most common livelihood of people in their Barangay is agriculture. Some are into rice planting businesses while others have livestock raising businesses.

With Vanjie’s previous loan requested through ASHI, she has been able to start raising cattle and supporting her rice planting business. These are raised just in her wide backyard where the land is covered with green grass and surrounded with rice plants. Once her cattle have been given a period of time to grow, they will be sold and the profit will be as much as double the capital (the same as the rice).

However, incomes in these kinds of businesses are seasonal, as well as the income of her husband, who is a farmer also. That is why Luzviminda thought of the need to have more savings so that she can provide her family with their daily needs. 

Through ASHI and its partnership with Kiva, Luzviminda would like to request a much larger loan amount to grow her business and to be able to have more profits as well as savings. For her business to be the greatest provider of money for her family, she needs to invest more capital in it.  She hoped that her savings would someday be enough to support the education of her three children, whose ages range from 10 to 19 years old.

Her eldest child, who no longer goes to school, is working as a cook in one of the fast food restaurants in town. His income is too small to be able to help his mother.

loans.use: To purchase cattle for fattening.

loans.name: Simbiat

texts.en: Simbiat is 45 years old and married with five children. Her husband is a trader who is into sales of foodstuffs. Simbiat sells kerosene and has been in this line of business for a long time. She has been a good client of the Kiva field partner, LAPO, for over 2 years. She is requesting a loan of 170,000 NGN. With the loan, she plans to expand her kerosene business, which is now booming. She hopes to increase her earnings over time and to be able to provide better for her children's education. She says thank you to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell.

loans.name: Oyebola

texts.en:
Oyebola is married to a civil servant and resides in Lagos. She is 40 years old and has three children. She is a member of the Kiva field partner, LAPO. Oyebola raises poultry, selling birds as well as eggs, and supplies her eggs to traders in large quantities.

She says her greatest challenges are insufficient capital to expand her business, purchasing sick chickens without knowing it, and the transportation costs, which are very high in the area due to her traveling to selling centers.

Oyebola needs a loan of 170,000 NGN to increase her inventory by purchasing more chicks to raise, with the aim of selling them to make more profit.

loans.use: To purchase more nursery birds for her poultry farm

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is engaged in a joint business with her husband: the molding and selling of cement blocks, a business they started way back in 1990. She is 45 years old, and the mother of five children. She is a member of the Kiva field partner, LAPO.

With the profit made from the business, her children’s school fees are taken care of, and they are provided with the basic necessities of life as enjoyed by other children.

Florence is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more cement and sand for the molding of blocks.

loans.use: To purchase more cement and sand

loans.name: Naome

texts.en:
Naome P. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste and beans and is requesting a loan to stock bags of rice and groundnuts to make paste to sell.  Naome is 26 years old and is married to a husband who is a policeman. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a beauty salon.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy stock bags of rice and groundnuts to make paste to sell.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary N. G. is fifty-three years old and married with three adult children. Her husband is in the same business and they hope to buy a plot and build their home. Her business is located at Mukuru Kwa Njenga in Nairobi where she has been selling timber to the local constructors for the last five years.

Her major challenge is the lack of enough funds, and that's why she is requesting a loan to buy more beams and timber to grow her business, open another timber yard and buy a lorry to enable her to supply her products to more customers. Mary is hardworking, disciplined, honest and caring.

loans.use: More beams and timber

loans.name: Modinot

texts.en:
Modinot is 46 years old and married with three children. She has been a member of the Kiva field partner, LAPO, for over two years now.

Modinot is the owner of Mummy Mutia Salon, where she displays her talent as a stylist. She also sells hair extensions and beauty accessories such as weaving materials, attachments, hair creams, etc. She started this business about 19 years ago, and she is not doing badly. She is a focused, hard worker. She puts in long hours trying to keep her business sustainable. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers. Modinot needs a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more hair extensions and beauty accessories, and other materials for her salon business.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and hair accessories and other materials for her salon.

loans.name: Kiden

texts.en:
Kiden R. is currently in the business of brewing and selling locally made liquor beverages from her home and is requesting a loan to stock more materials to use and crates of beer to sell.  Kiden is 30 years old and married. Her husband is a soldier. She has 4 children who attend school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a hotel.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock more materials to use and crates of beer to sell.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is 38 years old. He is married and the father of seven children. All his children are currently in school.

John is a very hard-working young man whose efforts bring hope and joy to his family. He does not downplay the importance of both business and family.

He trades in fishing nets, as he lives in a coastal area. He takes delivery of stock from Accra in the greater Accra region and sells them to the fishermen in the community. He has been in business for the last five years. He is requesting a loan to buy a supply of fishing nets in bulk. He is also a taxi driver and combines the two businesses successfully. He hopes to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: To buy a bulk supply of fishing nets.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is 43 years old. She is married and the mother of five children who are in school. Monica lives in Axim in the western region of Ghana. Axim is in the coastal area, and the major occupation for most women there is fish mongering and selling.

Monica buys a supply of fish from the seashore and smokes them by herself. She has customers from the greater Accra and the Ashanti region who buy from her in bulk. She prepares and serves her customers with very tasty and good quality fish, and because of that many customers buy from her stand.

She has seen much improvement in her business, but the main challenge is funds to buy more fish. Monica would use the loan to purchase good quality fish to supply her customers. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more fish

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji P. is currently in the business of selling cooked food in a restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock crates of beer and sodas to sell.  Keji is 28 years old and is married. Her  husband is a soldier. She has 3 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a hotel.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock crates of beer and sodas to sell

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort is 40 years old. She is married and the mother of two children who go to school. She lives at Axim in the western region of Ghana.

Axim is in the coastal area, and the major occupation for most women there is fish mongering and selling. Comfort takes a supply of fish from the seashore and smokes them. She has customers who come to buy them in bulk to re-sell to the final consumers.

Comfort also prepares and serves her customers with very tasty and good quality fish, and because of that many customers buy from her stand. Her business is progressing as a result of the good human relations she has with her customers.

Currently, her major problem has to do with funds to buy stock. Comfort would use the loan to purchase good quality fish to supply her customers. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
Ann K. is twenty-nine years old, married and has two children. Her husband is a sign maker.

Ann's business is located at Ongata Rongai near Tusky's supermarket and is known by the name of Amazing Grace Enterprises. The place is busy since it's on the roadside, so she is able to serve a big number of customers. She has been in this business for two years and her major challenges are the lack of working capital and the fact that many people are engaged in the same kind of business.

She is using her loan to buy more beauty accessories to sell. She hopes to grow her business into selling wholesale. She is a very aggressive lady.

loans.use: to buy more beauty accessories

loans.name: Lakulo

texts.en:
Lakulo J. is currently in the business of selling beans and maize flour in the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of rice and beans to sell.  Lakulo is 45 years old and married. Her husband is a peasant. She has 7 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay for the school fees for children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: stock bags of rice and beans to sell

loans.name: Vero

texts.en:
Vero is 55 years of age and married with three children. Vero sells shoes, clothing and sarongs, and has been in this line of business for the past fifteen years. She has been a good client of the Kiva field partner, LAPO, for over two years.

Vero is requesting a loan of 140,000 NGN. With the loan, she plans to expand her shoes and cloths (sarongs) business, which is now booming. With this kind of business she hopes to increase her earnings over time, and be able to provide better for her children's education.

She says thank you to Kiva and a big thank you to all who made the loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes and cloths (sarongs) to sell.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 48 years old, married, and the mother of four children. Currently, all four of her children are in school. Mary lives in Axim, in the western region of Ghana. Axim is in the coastal area, and the major occupation for most women there is fishmongering and selling.
Mary takes stocks of fish from the seashore and prepares them. She then smokes the fish and sells them to customers who buy them in bulk to sell to the end consumer. She serves her customers with very tasty and good quality fish and, because of that, many customers buy from Mary's stand. Her business is progressing as a result of the good customers relation she has fostered.
However, currently her major problem is a lack of funds to buy stock. Mary wants to use the loan facility to purchase good quality fish to supply to her customers. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy more stocks of fish and firewood

loans.name: Dieyla

texts.fr:
Madame Dieyla N. est une femme très  active de 52 ans qui habite à Ouakam.  Elle  est très connue a travers  sa fidélité et sa régularité au sein de l’U-IMCEC a la caisse de   Ouakam. En même temps qu’elle a démarré  ses activités  elle a aussi commence a travailler avec l’institution jusqu'à nos jours. Son activité  primaire est la commercialisation de légumes  et de produits locaux. Ce  qui l’a pousse a opte pour cette activité  c’est le fait qu’elle n’a jamais voulu rester oisive. Elle a toujours voulu gagner sa vie à la sueur de son front. Madame  N.  est veuve ayant en charge 6 enfants qui sont tous nourris et entretenus par elle-même. Elle est sociétaire  de la caisse de Ouakam depuis neuf ans et a déjà rembourse 9 prêts qui lui toujours permis de renforcer son capital, renforcer son activité primaire et même  créé  une activité de commerce de produits cosmétiques et divers  qu’elle se procure généralement  au Maroc. C’est une fierté  pour Madame Dieyla de voyager, d’être en contact avec beaucoup de gens, de découvrir  d’autres cultures. Elle est parent  bénéficiaire.
Toujours  dans son optique de participer activement a la lutte contre la pauvreté   l’U-IMCEC avec l’appui positif des prêteurs   réussit   à soutenir  les populations  a exercer des  activités  lucratives génératrices de revenus, ce  qui favorise un développement  socio économique   apprécié.
texts.en:
Mrs. Dieyla N., aged 52, is a very active woman who lives in Ouakam. She is well known and appreciated in the Ouakam branch of U-IMCEC, due to her loyalty and regularity. At the same time she launched her business, she became a client with our institution. Her primary activity is selling vegetables and local products. She chose this activity because she did not want to ever lead an idle life. She always wanted to make a living by the sweat of her brow.

Mrs. N. is a widow who provides alone for her six children. She has been a member of our Ouakam branch for nine years and repaid on schedule already nine loans. These loans enabled her to boost her working capital and bolster her primary business. They even enabled her to launch another activity, which is selling cosmetics and similar items that she usually buys in Morocco. Mrs. N. is proud to travel, be in contact with many people and discover other cultures. She will be the beneficiary of this loan.

Always looking to actively participate in the fight against poverty, U-IMCEC – with the positive support of lenders – succeeds in supporting women in revenue-generating activities which promote valuable socioeconomic development.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Sunset Group

texts.en:
Comfort is 29 years old, widowed, and the mother of four children, all of whom are currently in school. She enjoys selling goods to make a living, and has been selling foodstuffs such as tubers of yam, plantain, cassava, vegetable oil, etc. for five years now. Comfort treks to farming communities to buy her stock of foodstuffs from local farmers. This saves her from intermediaries who buy from the farmers and resell at a higher price. She wants to use her loan to buy in bulk to meet the daily demands of her customers over the Christmas festivities. She hopes to use part of her profit to support her children in school, and part to expand her business to the desired level. She would be grateful for your assistance.
Comfort is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Sunset’. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, food vendors, or farmers. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan. The group would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy yam, plantain, cassava, vegetable oil, etc. in bulk

loans.name: Iyabode

texts.en:
Iyabode is 49 years old, married, and has three children. She lives in Lagos, Nigeria. Iyabode is a member of Kiva partner, Lift Above Poverty Organization, and has a good repayment record. She owns a pharmacy shop where she sells medicines to customers at retail. Iyabode manages the business while her children assist her in the shop after school.
Income from her business enables Iyabode to support her husband in feeding and educating their children. Iyabode is very determined and want to expand the size of her business, having an additional store where she can sell medicines and make more profit. She is requesting a loan of 70,000 NGN to purchase more medicines to expand her business and meet customer demand.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Ilori

texts.en:
Ilori is 38 years old, married, and has four children. She lives in Lagos, Nigeria. Ilori is hardworking and believes that women are helpmates to support men in keeping the home.
Ilori is a hairdresser and she also sells jewelry, hair extensions, and other accessories to make an additional profit. With the profit from her business she is able to save a little money and assist her husband in running the home. Ilori hopes to expand her business, and is requesting a loan of 70,000 NGN to purchase more accessories to sell. She sends her thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and accessories to sell

loans.name: Sairambi

texts.ru: Сайрамби Хидирова проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст 48 лет. Разведена, имеет 5 детей. Сайрамби более 10 лет проработала по своей специальности "педагогом". Вот как более 6 лет занимается торговлей на рынке. Она в основном торгует хоз. товарами. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Sairambi H. lives in the city of Kulob. She is forty-eight-years-old and divorced with five children. She spent more than ten years working as a teacher. Since then, she has been a vendor at the market for more than six years, selling mainly household goods. She plans to use her loan to increase inventory.

Translated from Russian by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth N. M. is 45 years old, married, and has two school-aged children. Her husband is a security guard at International House in Nairobi. The couple hope to build a home and educate their children to college level. Elizabeth is innovative, hardworking, caring, and honest.
Elizabeth's business is at Pipeline and is known as Leems Beauty Shop. She sells beauty products to supermarkets, salons, and local people. She also engages in midwifery. Her major challenges are lack of funds, harassment from the local authority, and few permanent customers. She is using her loan to buy more hair extensions, hair chemicals, and treatments, and to open a small general store. In the future, she hopes to open a beauty supermarket.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and treatments, and to open a small general store

loans.name: Bumi

texts.en:
Bumi is 44 years old, married, and has five children. Her two eldest children are in secondary school while the younger ones are in primary school. Bumi is a businesswoman who lives and works in Lagos. For the last ten years she has made a living by running a retail business selling drinks to customers. As a hardworking woman, she also runs a rental service in order to make additional profit. With the profits from her business, she is able to support and sustain her family financially.
Bumi is requesting a loan of 180,000 NGN to purchase more drinks to sell, especially during the festive season when there is an increase in demand and therefore an opportunity to make more profit. She sends her thanks all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Regina's Group

texts.en:
Regina is 36 years old and a married mother of three children. Two of her children are currently with their father in Cote d’Ivoire, which is Ghana’s neighboring country, while she takes care of the lastborn here in Ghana. For the last eight years, Regina has run a business selling lingerie for women, such as bras, panties, etc., and it is very profitable. She takes delivery of stock from Accra and sells it in smaller quantities through hawking. She wants to use her loan to buy bales of lingerie and jeans materials to increase her inventory and sales as we celebrate Christmas. She believes this loan will help her save some money to start paying her utility bills and part of the children’s school fees.
Regina is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Oyerepa’, which means 'good wife'. She is pictured standing third from right in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders, grocery shop operators, or food vendors. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan. The group would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy bales of lingerie and jeans materials

loans.name: Risolat

texts.ru: Содикова Рисолат проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст 51 лет. Вдова, имеет 3 детей. Рисолат имеет среднее образование. Она более 14 лет занимается торговлей на рынке. В ее ассортимент входит основном одежда. Кредит просит для расширения ассортимента, т.е. увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Risolat S. lives in Kulyab. She is 51. Risolat S. is a widow and a mother of 3 children. She has a high school education. For more than 14 years, Risolat has been selling clothing at a local market. She asks for this loan to increase the assortment of goods she sells and to help drive sales up.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase the volume of goods sold

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Kuvvat

texts.ru: Кувват Сайфуллоев проживает в городе Куляб. Возраст 53 года. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Кувват имеет среднее образование. Он более 7 лет занимается производством у себя дома. Кувват производит национальную посуду. Кредит просит для закупа сырья, чтобы предоставлять качественные услуги.
texts.en:
Kuvvat S. lives in Kulyab. He is 53, married, and has 4 children. Kuvvat has high school education. For more than 7 years, Kuvvat has been making traditional Tadzhik pottery. He requested this loan to purchase quality raw materials.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of raw materials

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Bayram

texts.en: Bayram S. was born in 1950. He is married and has two children. Bayram lives in Baku city, and has been in building houses business for 3 years. Now, in order to improve his business, he is requesting a loan of 2,000 AZN to  buy the necessary materials for building houses.

loans.use: To buy materials for building houses

loans.name: Precious Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 50 years old, widowed, and the mother of three children. Her youngest child is in school while the rest are working. Elizabeth operates a drinking spot where she sells all kinds of soft drinks, such as canned malts, and canned and bottled drinks such as Coke, Pepsi, etc. She is an achiever and her focus is to save enough to provide for her business and give her youngest child a good quality education.
However, Elizabeth says that without adequate funds it is not possible to realize that dream. She has been running the drinking spot for 15 years now, and she is requesting a loan to buy assorted drinks to upgrade her inventory. She would be grateful for your assistance.
Elizabeth is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Precious’. She is pictured standing second from the left in the group photograph. Most of the members of this group are petty traders and food sellers. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access the loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy assorted drinks to upgrade her inventory

loans.name: Blessing

texts.en:
Blessing is 30 years old and is happily married to Mr. C., a civil servant. They live in Lagos State. Blessing is a trader and makes a living by running a retail business selling mobile phone recharge cards. She is a client of Kiva partner, Lift Above Poverty Organization, and belongs to Udo group. She pays her loans as and when due.
Blessing hopes to expand her shop from retail to wholesale. For this purpose, she has been able to save a little from her profits. However, this will not be enough so she is requesting a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase a large quantity of mobile phone recharge cards at a discount. In this way, she hopes to increase sales and make more profit. She sends her thanks to Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more mobile phone recharges cards to sell

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 27 years old, married, and has two children. One of her children is in school while the other is still breastfeeding. Beatrice lives with her family in a community in the western region of Ghana. She works tirelessly to support her husband in taking care of the children.
Beatrice owns and operates a beauty salon in her neighborhood and also sells cosmetics products. She is a very skillful and talented hairdresser with six years of hairdressing experience. For this reason, many clients visit her salon. Beatrice believes in efficiency and effectiveness of service, and therefore wants to use her loan to buy larger quantities of hair products such as assorted wigs, pomade, shampoo, activators, hairdryer machines etc., to serve her customers well. She would be grateful for your assistance and support.

loans.use: To buy hair products such as wigs, pomade, shampoo, activators, etc.

loans.name: Bola

texts.en:
Bola is 32 years old, married with two children and in primary school. Her husband is a roadside motor mechanic. She bakes and sells snacks and groceries. She has been in this business of snack sales for some time. With the profit from her business, she helps to support her husband financially.

Bola wants to add more to her business activities that will help generate more income. She hopes for a loan of N100,000 to purchase a grinding machine for grinding tomatoes, corn, pepper etc. This she can work with when she is less busy in her snacks business.

She is a committed LAPO client. She thanks all lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more baking items and a grinding machine.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is 30 years old and a married mother with two children. Both of her children are in school. Esther is an enthusiastic business woman who works to provide for her children. She does not relax when it comes to business as she claims it is the only source of income for the family. She is a trader and sells lingerie like bras and panties, assorted soaps and baby diapers, etc. She sells her goods through hawking (that is house-to-house selling). She takes delivery of stock from Accra and sells the stock through hawking in smaller quantities. She wants to use the loan to buy bales of lingerie, soaps, and diapers in bulk to increase her inventory and sales for good income as we celebrate Christmas. She believes this loan would help her save some money to start paying part of the children’s school fees and utility bills.

loans.use: To buy bales of lingerie, soaps and diapers

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia is 40 years old, married and mother of three children. All of her children are currently in school. She is a very hard-working woman and works hard to support her business and her children in school. She trades in flip-flops, Ghana-made slippers, shoes and sandals for both sexes. She takes delivery of stock from Accra in Ghana. She purchases them in different sizes, colors and designs so that her customers can make their choice. She mostly sells them through hawking (that is, house to house selling) and sometimes in the community on market day. She has no regrets with this business as it brings her satisfaction. In spite of keen competition in the market, she manages to make sales all day. She requests your loan assistance to buy stock in bulk. She would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To buy flip-flops and Ghana-made slippers in bulk from Accra.

loans.name: Navdagul
