She currently serves as president of the group. Mirtha has been selling beauty products through a catalog for three years. In addition, she produces hand woven articles. Through the effort of her daily work, Mirtha is able to cover the educational costs for her children. Her greatest dream is to see them become professionals. Mirtha used her recent loan to put a roof on her house. All of the members are thankful for the support and promises to make their payments on the established due dates.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: German

texts.es: El Sr. German se dedica a la actividad de muñonero y tambien hace el cambiado de pastillas y balatas actividad con la que mantiene a su hogar que esta integrado por dos hijos pequeños y la esposa,quien le ayuda en el taller, se pudo ver que el cliente es muy trabajador ya que esta surgiendo poco a poco, tambien es muy conocido y tiene bastante clientela por la zona ya que realiza muy bien su trabajo, por todo lo mensionado se escogio al cliente para el credito kiva.
texts.en:
Sr. German works as an auto mechanic. Among the services he provides are alignments and brake pad changes. He and his wife manage this business out of their home in order to support their two small children. His customers notice that he is a very hard worker who is constantly growing little by little. He has developed a good reputation and has built up a decent clientele because he does very good work. It should be mentioned that it was for this reason he was chosen to receive a loan through Kiva.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase tools for his work

loans.name: Eduardo

texts.es:
Eduardo tiene 42 años de edad, es casado y vive junto a su esposa y cinco de sus seis hijos en el distrito de Paiján, provincia de Ascope, en la región La Libertad, ubicada a 3 horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica al servicio de vulcanizado de llantas de todo tipo de vehículo desde hace 25 años, aprendió este oficio de un amigo de su padre y gracias a esta actividad ha sustentado a su familia durante todo este tiempo. Eduardo trabaja todos los días desde las siete de la mañana hasta las siete de la noche. Su establecimiento se encuentra ubicado a un costado de la carretera Panamericana (la principal via asfaltada del país que atraviesa la ciudad), lo que favorece la demanda de sus servicios.

Por otro lado complementa su negocio con la venta de cámaras para autos, empezó este negocio desde el año 2002 y gracias a él puede aportar una cantidad adicional a los ingresos familiares. Eduardo desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más cámaras para venta por lo que se encuentra solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles.

Su más grande anhelo es seguir trabajando para modernizar su negocio y sacar adelante a los suyos. El ya ha trabajado anteriormente con nuestra Institución y ha demostrado ser un cliente puntual y responsable al momento de asumir sus pagos.
texts.en:
Eduardo is 42 years old, married, and lives with his wife and five of his six children in the District of Paiján in Ascope Province. This community is in the region of La Libertad, which is located three hours away from the city of Chiclayo.

Eduardo provides tire vulcanization services for all types of vehicles. He has been in this business for 25 years and learned the trade from a friend of his father. This business has allowed him to support his family throughout this entire time. Eduardo works every day from 7am to 7pm. His business is located along the Pan American Highway (the main paved road that crosses the city), which helps to attract demand for his services.

As a complementary side business, he sells inner tubes for automobiles. He started this business in 2002 as a way of providing additional income for his family. Eduardo wants to expand this business by purchasing more inner tubes, so he is requesting a loan from Edpyme Alternativa in the amount of 1000 soles.

His greatest desire is to continue working so that he can modernize his business and succeed on behalf of his family. Eduardo has previously worked with our Institution, so he has demonstrated that he is a punctual and responsible client when it comes to making his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase inner tubes for automobile tires

loans.name: Kamamemi Group

texts.en: Makaprr Koroma is approximately forty-seven years old. She is the leader of this group called Kamamemi (a Temne phrase meaning “Give me a try”). She and her fellow group members are small-scale businesswomen in Magburaka town, in northern Sierra Leone who want a loan of SLL 500,000 each to boost their businesses. The group’s leader, Makaprr is married with three children; one of her children is attending secondary school and two are in college. Makaprr sells market food – palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), rice and many more items. She has been in this business for many years.  With her share of this loan, she will add more stock to her business; she will specifically buy a bag of peppers, a bag of rice, onions, tomatoes, margi, and a bag of salt.

loans.use: Buy a bag of peppers, a bag of rice, onions, tomatoes, margi, and a bag of salt

loans.name: Las Azucenas Group

texts.es:
Las Azucenas es una alcancía comunal conformada por 10 socios entusiastas y emprendedores, quienes se dedican a actividades D. comercio minorista, trabajan con EDAPROSPO- prosperidad desD. hace 5 años.
Julia con 43 años, conviviente, tiene 7 hijos D. 5, 9, 11, 16, 19,23 y 25 años, asume el cargo D. presidenta.
Julia y su esposo se dedican a la fabricación y comercialización D. chompas D. lana, alpaca e hilo desD. hace 12 años,  quienes con esfuerzo y dedicación  han logrado adquirir una maquina tejedora, comprar su terreno y mejorar así su nivel D. vida.
Nuestros socios con el reciente préstamo lo destinaremos para la compra D. mercadería, agradecen el apoyo brindado y se comprometen en la puntualidad D. sus pagos.
texts.en:
Las Azucenas is a communal credit union maD. up of 10 enthusiastic and enterprising members who are dedicated to wholesale commerce. They have worked with EDAPROSPO Prosperity for 5 years.

Julia, currently the president, is 43 years old, living in a stable relationship, and has 7 children, aged 5, 9, 11, 16, 19, 23, and 25. Julia and her husband have dedicated 12 years to making and selling sweaters of wool, alpaca, and thread. With much effort and dedication they have acquired a sewing machine and bought their own land, and thus improved their standard of living.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY MERCHANDISE TO SELL

loans.name: Juber Eduardo

texts.es:
Juber tiene 32 años de edad, es soltero y vive junto a su familia en el distrito de Paiján, provincia de Ascope, en la región La Libertad, ubicada a tres horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica al trabajo agrícola desde que tiene quince años. Empezó ayudando a su padre en sus cultivos y luego ingresó a trabajar en una empresa agricola de la zona. Actualmente se desempeña como obrero agrícola y trabaja seis días a la semana. Adicionalmente ha sembrado maíz hace dos meses en un terreno de su padre y se encarga de cuidar de este cultivo en sus tiempos libres.

Durante las horas del día en que no se encuentra trabajando en el campo maneja una mototaxi (vehículo motorizado utilizado en el transporte de carga y pasajeros) de propiedad de su hermano. Los ingresos que percibe de estas actividades los utiliza para solventar sus gastos personales y ayudar al sostenimiento de su familia.

Juber se encuentra solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que piensa invertir en la compra de fertilizantes y pesticidas para el mantenimiento de su cultivo de maíz.

Juber desea seguir trabajando para poder ayudar a su familia. El ya ha trabajado anteriormente con nuestra Institución y ha demostrado responsabilidad y puntualidad al momento de asumir sus cuotas. En la fotografía aparece brindando servicio de transporte en las calles de Paiján.
texts.en:
Juber is 32 years old, unmarried and lives with his family in the district of Paiján, province of Ascope, in the region of La Libertad, which is located three hours from the city of Chiclayo. He has been working in agriculture since he was fifteen years old. He began by helping his father with his crops and later began working for a nearby agriculture company. He works as an agriculture worker six days a week. In addition, he planted corn seeds two months ago on his father's land and is cultivating the crop in his spare time. When he is not working in the field he drives a mototaxi (a motorized vehicle used to transport passengers and cargo) that is owned by his brother. The income he earns from these activities is used to pay for his personal expenses and to help support his family. Juber is requesting a loan for 1,000 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa. He will use the loan to purchase fertilizer and pesticides to help nurture his corn crop. Juber would like to keep working so that he can help his family. He has worked previously with our Institution and has demonstrated responsibility and punctuality with his loan payments. In the photograph above he is working at his transportation job in the streets of Paiján.

Translated from Spanish by Matthew Raimondi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pesticides to help nurture his corn crop.

loans.name: Walter Alfonso

texts.es:
Walter tiene 42 años de edad, es casado y vive junto a su esposa y sus tres hijos en el distrito de Paiján, provincia de Ascope, en la región La Libertad, ubicado a tres horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a trabajar como obrero eventual, pero debido a que esta actividad no le brindaba la estabilidad que necesitaba para solventar los gastos familiares empezó a vender cerveza en su domicio hace tres años. Walter ofrece este producto a sus vecinos, especialmente los fines de semana.

El negocio goza de buena acogida debido al buen trato que perciben los clientes. Walter desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más cerveza por lo que se encuentra solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles.

Su más grande anhelo es llegar a convertirse en distribuidor mayorista y comprar una movilidad para distribuir su producto en las todas las tiendas de Paiján y anexos. El ya ha trabajado anteriormente con nuestra Institución, demostrando puntualidad y responsabilidad al momento de asumir sus pagos.
texts.en:
Walter is 42 years old, married, and lives with his wife and their three children in Paiján district, Ascope province, La Libertad region, located three hours from Chiclayo city. He works as a temporary laborer, but this work doesn’t provide the stability that he needs to meet his household expenses. He began to sell beer in his home 3 years ago. Walter offers this product to his neighbors, especially on weekends. The business is going well due to the good service he provides his customers. Walter wishes to expand his business with the purchase of more beer so he is asking Edpyme Alternativa for a 1000 nuevos soles loan. His greatest goal is to become a wholesale distributor and buy a vehicle to distribute his product in all the stores in Paiján and the surrounding area. He has worked previously with our Institution, demonstrating punctuality and responsibility with his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy beer to expand his business

loans.name: Luis Elvis

texts.es:
Luis tiene 22 años de edad, es soltero y vive junto a su madre y su hermana en el sector La Arenita, en el distrito de Paiján, provincia de Ascope, en la región La Libertad, ubicada a tres horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

La necesidad de colaborar con el sostenimiento de su familia hizo que desde que tuviera quince años de edad empezara a trabajar como jornalero en algunos campos de cultivo de la zona. Actualmente se gana la vida como recolector y seleccionador de tomates en un terreno cercano.

Por otro lado está estudiando una carrera técnico agropecuaria en un instituto de la zona. Luis se encuentra solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles que piensa utilizar en mejorar el techo de su vivienda, ya que las lluvias que se presentan durante los meses de verano siempre hacen estragos en las casas de la zona.

Luis sueña con poder terminar sus estudios y empezar a trabajar en una empresa grande que que le asegure el sostenimiento y bienestar que necesita. El es un joven trabajador y responsable, sus vecinos y conocidos lo estiman mucho.
texts.en:
Luis is 22 years old, unmarried and lives with his mother and sister in the La Arenita sector in the district of Paiján, province of Ascope, in the region of La Libertad, located three hours from the city of Chiclayo. Because of the need to help support his family, Luis has been working as a laborer in the nearby agricultural fields since he was fifteen. He works picking and selecting tomatoes in a nearby tract of land. When he is not working in the fields he studies for a technical career in agriculture at a nearby institute. This is Luis' first loan with Edpyme Alternativa and he is requesting a loan for 1,000 nuevos soles to improve the roof of his dwelling. During the summer months the rains ravage the houses in his area. Luis' dream is to finish his studies and begin working at a large company that will help to sustain him and support his needs. He is a young hard worker and his neighbors and friends think very highly of him.

Translated from Spanish by Matthew Raimondi, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To improve the roof of his dwelling.

loans.name: María Elena

texts.es:
María Elena tiene 50 años de edad, es madre soltera y vive junto a sus tres hijos y una sobrina en el sector Pilar Nores, distrito de Paiján, provincia de Ascope, en la región La Libertad, ubicado a tres horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Desde hace más de quince años tiene instalada en su vivienda un pequeña bodega donde ofrece a sus clientes productos de primera necesidad, abarrotes y bebidas. Ella nos comenta que su negocio fue uno de los primeros en la zona y que actualmente goza de buena acogida entre sus clientes ya que sus clientes siempre confían en la calidad de sus productos y servicios. Este negocio es su única fuente de ingresos económico son la que sustenta a su familia.

Ella se encuentra solicitando a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles para ampliar su negocio con la compra de productos de primera necesidad que le permitan obtener más ganancias y así invertir en la educación de una hija que estudia enfermería en un instituto de la zona.

Su más grande anhelo es ver a su hija convertida en una enfermera de éxito. Ella ya ha trabajado anteriormente con nuestra Institución y ha demostrado ser una clienta puntual y responsable.
texts.en:
50-year old María Elena is a single mother and lives with her three children and niece in the Pilar Nores neighbourhood of Paiján District in the province of Ascope, La Libertad region, which is located three hours from the city of Chiclayo. More than fifteen years ago María Elena opened a small store in her home where she sells basic supplies, groceries, and drinks to her customers. She notes that her business was one of the first in the area and she enjoys a warm welcome there because her customers can always trust the quality of her products and service. The business is María Elena’s sole source of income and provides for her family’s needs. She is asking for a loan of S/.1000 from Kiva partner Edpyme Alternativa to buy basic necessities and thus expand her business. This will allow her to earn more money so she pay for the education of her daughter who is studying to be a nurse in a local institution. Her greatest wish is to see her daughter become a successful nurse. She has worked with our organisation in the past and has proven to be punctual and responsible with her loan repayments.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy basic supplies for her corner store

loans.name: Yessica

texts.es:
Nuestra socia Yessica tiene 31 años, es casada y tiene 2 hijos: Samanta tiene 12 años y Fabricio tiene 6 años.  La socia Yessica vive en la ciudad de Calca del departamento del Cusco y pertenece al Banco Comunal “MAMACHA ASUNTA” de la Asociación Arariwa.  
La socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que se levanta muy temprano para hacer sus actividades en la casa como por ejemplo preparar desayuno para sus hijos y su esposo y también limpia los dormitorios de sus hijos. La socia después de hacer sus actividades de la casa tiene que ir a instalar su pequeño negocio de venta de instrumentales musicales que ella misma los fabrica a base de carrizo y madera. La socia nos cuenta que tiene que acomodar en su puesto de negocio los instrumentos en el stand provisional que la municipalidad de Pisaq les cedió. La municipalidad le alquila a la socia un espacio en la Plaza de Armas de Pisaq para que venda sus productos. Ya son varios años que se dedica al negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su negocio. La socia requiere el préstamo para comprar más materiales como madera especial para la fabricación de Instrumentos musicales como guitarras, charangos, mandolinas, zampoñas y quenas. La socia nos cuenta que antes se dedicaba a la venta de artesanía y que por falta de apoyo no podía seguir con el negocio pero ahora con el préstamo volverá a comprar más productos como collares de cerámica y mucho más.       

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Our member Yessica is 31 years old, married, and has two children: Samanta is 12 years old and Fabricio is 6 years old. Yessica lives in Calca city, Cusco department, and belongs to the Communal Bank “MAMACHA ASUNTA” in the Arariwa Association. Yessica is a hard-working and enterprising mother who gets up very early to do her housework such as preparing breakfast for her children and husband and also cleaning her children’s bedrooms. She then does her housework, she has to open her small musical instrument business she has in her home. She makes the instruments herself out of reed and wood. She tells us that she has a temporary stand in Pisaq municipality. The municipality rents an association member space in the Plaza de Armas of Pisaq to sell products. She has had this business for various years and it is going well thanks to the effort she puts into her business. She requires a loan to buy maore materials such as wood from which to make instruments such as guitars, small guitars, mandolins, and quenas. She tells us that previously she sold artisan pieces but because of the lack of support she wasn’t able to continue with the business but now with the loan she will again buy more products such as ceramic necklaces and other items. Yessica is grateful for the opportunity provided through this loan and she promises to make all her payments according to the repayment schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy wood and artisan items

loans.name: Cristo Rey De Nicolas De Piérola Group

texts.es:
CRISTO REY D. NICOLAS D. PIEROLA

La alcancía comunal Cristo Rey D. Nicolás D. Piérola cursa su séptimo ciclo, sus once integrantes son personas microempresarias que a través D. sus negocios apoyan en la económica D. su hogar y a futuro mejorar su calidad D. vida. Tales son los casos D.: Angélica C. y Nora C..
Angélica, tengo 41 años D. edad, soy madre D. dos hijos (uno mayor D. edad y el otro catorce). 
Me inicié D. microempresaria desD. chiquilla, al principio lo hacía para ayudar a una amiga así la apoyaba en ofrecer sus productos D. belleza a mis amistades y conocidos a cambio D. ello me regalaba alguna monería. Pocos años más tarD. decidí inscribirme como consultora D. belleza lo que puD. darme cuenta que este negocio es rentable, trabajar independiente me permite además D. tiempo para dedicarme al cuidado D. mi hijo. También opté por vender uniformes escolares para escuelas particulares invirtiendo las ganancias D. este último negocio en mercadería a fin D. incrementar mis ingresos más tarD.. Así sucedió las ganancias mejoraron empleándolo en la educación a mis hijos, el último estudia en una escuela particular y apoyo a mi esposo en los gastos D. mi familia. El crédito que necesito es para comprar mercadería D. ropa D. baño pues se acerca la estación D. verano.

Nora, tengo 56 años y antes D. que mi esposo falleciera solo me dedicaba al cuidado D. mi familia porque a él nunca le agradó la idea que trabajara.
Empecé a sentir que la tristeza y depresión me estaba consumiendo emocionalmente, lo que decidí fue ocupar mi tiempo en trabajar en algo independiente pues siempre quise hacerlo. Es así que opté en inscribirme como consultora D. belleza hace más D. dos años, el trato que brindo a mis clientes me hizo captar con el tiempo más compradores, agradezco a Dios por apoyarme todo este tiempo. Me siento contenta y reconfortable porque he recibido premios por ser una D. las líderes que mayor venta hace. Actualmente estoy en tres líneas inscrita (Avon, Esika, Unique) y a las personas que trabajan ayudándome a vender los productos las motivo a que con el tiempo sean también líderes.
texts.en:
CRISTO REY D. NICOLAS D. PIEROLA The Cristo Rey D. Nicolás D. Piérola Community Bank is on its seventh loan cycle. Its eleven members are small-business people who, through their businesses, contribute to household income and improvements to their quality of life in the future. Such is the case of Angélica C. and Nora C.. Angélica: I am 41 years old and have two children, one of whom is grown up and the other is 14. I started working in a small business when I was a young girl. At the beginning I did it to help a friend who was selling beauty products. I sold them to my friends and acquaintances, and in exchange she gave me small gifts. A few years later I decided to take a beauty consultant’s course. I realised that it could be a profitable venture. Also working in my own business allows me to care for my son. I also decided to sell private school uniforms and invested the profits from this business in merchandise with the goal of increasing my income later on. And so it happened that I earned more and used the money to educate my children. The youngest is in a private school. I help my husband pay for the family’s expenses. I need the loan to buy swimsuits as the summer season is approaching. Nora: I am 56 years old, and before my husband died I spent my time bringing up my family as he did not like the idea of my working. I started to feel that sadness and depression were destroying me emotionally, so I decided that I would use my time working in my own business, something I had always wanted to do. I took a beauty consultant’s course more than two years ago. The good service I proviD. has meant that over time my clients have increased in number. I thank God for helping me all this time. I feel happy and content because I have received awards for being one of the team leaders with the most sales. I now sell three beauty lines (Avon, Esika, and Unique), and I encourage my assistants to also become team leaders.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy swimsuits

loans.name: Unidos Por El Triunfo Group

texts.es:
UNIDOS POR EL TRIUNFO

Grupo conformado por diez mujeres emprendedoras, quienes se vieron en la necesidad D. trabajar independiente para mantener a los miembros D. su familia. En esta oportunidad conoceremos un poco más a otros D. sus integrantes: 

Yolanda tiene 50 años D. edad, hace más D. ocho años venD. productos D. belleza fue por una amistad que la motivó trabajar así debido a la separación D. su esposo cuando sus hijos tenían 15 y 12 años. Yolanda trabajaba en ese entonces como auxiliar en un centro educativo del estado, puso todas las ganas en vender sus productos a sus conocidos, amigos, profesores, padres D. familia; con el tiempo decidió inscribirse en otras líneas cosméticas como consultora D. belleza (Esika, Avon, Natura) las ganancias D. estas resultaron rentables para ello requirió D. un capital empleando el dinero en mercadería para su negocio. Su esfuerzo y el deseo D. superarse no dejó D. cumplir su deber D. madre así proporcionó alimentación, ropa, y apoyó en el estudio universitario a su hijo quien estudia ingeniería electrónica, éste no recibe del todo el apoyo D. su padre.  Tuvo altibajos su negocio el motivo fue cuando su hijo se enfermó ocasionándole gastos en atención médica y tratamiento, poco después se recuperó D. ello lo que posteriormente compró una pequeña refrigeradora para su hogar. Necesita del préstamo para invertir en mercadería D. cosméticos y espera tener más adelante una vivienda propia porque hace nueve años vive y es guardiana D. un centro inicial.

Angélica tiene 39 años, trabajé empezando a vender golosinas hace nueve años en una carreta, esto lo hacía afuera D. los colegios estatales, así mismo los fines D. semana iba con mi canasta a los parques, estadio y en fiestas patronales ofreciendo mis golosinas en la zona D. Chosica – Perú por lo general era en horas D. la tarD. y noche porque en las mañanas me dedicaba a los quehaceres del hogar. Los préstamos que recibí lo invertí en mercadería (maní, habas, cancha, gaseosas, galletas, piqueos, caramelos). D. igual forma hago trabajos en tejido a crochet y palitos como ajuares para bebés, boleros, chompa, gorros, ponchos a los que le pongo aplicación D. mostacilla, canutillo, conchitas, maderitas D. acuerdo a la moda, y a los pedidos D. mis clientes. Actualmente tengo pedidos D. ajuares y boleros para ello requiero el préstamo para invertir en crochet, palitos, hijo y lana D. color. Las ganancias que obtengo D. este trabajo ayudo a mi esposo en la educación a mis hijos, ropa y alimentación.
texts.en:
Unidos Por El Trunfo (United for the Victory)

This group consists of ten enterprising women who saw the need to work independently in order to support the members of their families. We take this opportunity to know a few of the members a little bit better.

Yolanda is 50 years old and has been selling beauty products for more than eight years. A friend convinced her to work after she separated from her husband when her children were 15 and 12 years of age. At the time, Yolanda was working as an assistant at a state school. She offers her products with great enthusiasm to acquaintances, friends, teachers, and parents at the school. Over time she decided to sign up to proviD. cosmetics from various lines (Esika, Avon, and Natura) and become a beauty consultant. Her business is profitable because the only capital required is the money needed to purchase merchandise for her inventory. Yolanda’s hard work and desire to succeed have enabled her to fulfill her duty as a mother to proviD. food, clothing, and an education for her son who is studying electrical engineering. Her ex-husband no longer provides financial support. Her business went through some ups and downs as a result of paying for medical expenses and treatment when her son became ill. He recovered quickly and afterwards she was able to buy a small refrigerator for her home. She is requesting a loan to purchase cosmetics. She hopes to have a house of her own sometime later because she has been a caretaker at a children’s home for the past nine years.

Angélica is 39 years old. She began working nine years ago by selling candy out of a cart that she parked outsiD. of the state schools. On the weekends, she carried a basket of candy to sell at parks, stadiums, and patron saint festivals in the district of Chosica. She normally sells in the afternoons and evenings because she spends her mornings performing her household chores. The loans she has received have been used to purchase merchandise (peanuts, beans, popcorn, soft drinks, cookies, snacks, and candy). In addition she crochets and knits items such as baby outfits, jackets, sweaters, caps, and ponchos. Angélica also does appliqués with beads, tassels, shells, strips of wood, or whatever material is in fashion and requested by her customers. She currently has outstanding orders for dresses and jackets, so she needs a loan to purchase crochet needles and colored wool. Her earnings will enable to help her husband with paying for food, clothing, and education for their children.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Los Tunales Group

texts.es:
Llamada así esta alcancía comunal por el cultivo D. tuna en la zona llamado San Bartolomé y TornaM. es allí donD. se extrae además la cochinilla que es empleado para la coloración D. prendas textiles, sus doce integrantes son personas responsables, microempresarias quienes se dedican en vender frutas, golosinas, comida.

Yanet es madre soltera y tiene 48 años D. edad, la necesidad D. criar a sus hijos la impulsó a vender frutas en su casa que está ubicada en la carretera central, levantándose muy temprano para comprar la mercadería en el mercado mayorista D. frutas, aprovecha expender tuna, melocotones, manzana y mandarinas a los ómnibus, camiones y autos que visitan la sierra central; también venD. gasolina y petróleo a los autos que circulan en la zona.  D. igual modo en las mañanas se encarga D. cuidar los tubos D. agua D. su comunidad. El primer crédito que recibió compró gaseosas, kekes, galletas, utilizando las ganancias en adquirir una vitrina para sus golosinas, una refrigeradora e insumos. Como podemos apreciar en la fotografía el negocio D. Yanet ha ido mejorando con el tiempo, con ello paga los gastos D. su familia, dio la carrera D. farmacia a su hija, y sigue apoyando en la actualidad a su última hija quien estudia computación e informática, costea los medicamentos para su enfermedad (osteoporosis), así mismo construyó un baño D. material noble. El préstamo que necesita es para invertir una parte en gaseosas, golosinas y la otra apoyará en los trámites D. titulación D. su hija egresada. 

María es conviviente, tiene dos hijos D. 20 y 7 años venD. dulces en su casa así comparte en los gastos del hogar con su esposo quien es cobrador D. micro y por ello a veces no siempre tiene trabajo. Los préstamos que recibió lo invirtió en mercadería para adquirir gaseosas, galletas, detergentes los ingresos que obtiene son regulares. La comunidad también le dio a María un trabajo eventual para que se encargue D. soltar el agua en las mañanas. El préstamo que requiere es para comprar galletas y gaseosas.
texts.en:
This Communal Bank is named for the prickly pear cacti that grow in the districts of San Bartolomé and TornaM.. From this area comes cochineal (an insect that lives off the prickly pear cactus) extract that is used for dyeing textiles. The twelve members of this group are responsible micro-entrepreneurs who engage in selling fruit, candy, and food.

Yanet is a 48 year old single mother. The need to support her children prompted her to sell fruit from her home, which is located along the main highway. She wakes up early to buy her merchandise in bulk at the wholesale fruit market. She offers prickly pears, peaches, apples, and tangerines to people who are traveling to the mountains by bus, truck, or car. Yanet also sells gasoline and oil for cars that pass through the area. In addition, in the mornings, she is in charge of maintaining the water pipes for her community. Her first loan was used to purchase sodas, pound cakes, and cookies. She used her earnings to buy a display case for storing candy, a refrigerator, and supplies for her business. The group photograph was taken at Yanet’s business, so we can see that she has been improving over time. Yanet has been able to pay for her family’s expenses and help one of her daughters earn her pharmacy degree. She is currently supporting her youngest daughter who is studying information technology, paying for her own osteoporosis medication, and constructing a bathroom with solid materials. The loan she is requesting will be used to purchase soft drinks and candy. Part of the proceeds will also be used to pay for her daughter’s college registration fees.

María is in a common law marriage and has two children, ages 20 and 7. She sells candy from home and also shares the household expenses with her husband, who works as a small-time debt collector. However, there are times when he does not have work. The loans she has received have been used to buy soft drinks, cookies, and detergents. Her earnings have been steady. The community has given María the responsibility of releasing the water in the mornings. Her loan will be used to purchase cookies and soft drinks.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Union Collana Group

texts.es:
UNION COLLANA

En esta alcancía participan once personas microempresarias la mayoría de ellos son agricultores, a través de sus negocios consiguen el sustento en sus hogares, darle lo mejor a los suyos es uno de sus muchos objetivos. Así pues conoceremos el testimonio de Adrían quien es el tesorero del grupo más de dos años y medio. 
Es agricultor desde hace más de diez años, sus padres le cedieron una tierras lo cual aprovecha en sembrar alfalfa es lo que más produce y obtiene mayor rentabilidad porque se cosecha hasta seis veces al año. Como todo padre quiere darles lo mejor a sus dos hijos de 11 y 6 años adicionó en cultivar frutas como manzana, membrillo y algunos tubérculos como choclo, arvejas, espinaca, papa. Para ello necesitó del préstamo para la compra de semillas, fertilizantes, pesticidas, abono foliares, herbecidas. Los productos son vendidos a los compradores del mercado mayoristas. 
De esta manera Adrián comparte los gastos con su esposa en educar a sus niños, vestimenta, alimentación, así mismo llegó a adquirir algunos electrodomésticos que antes no tenían de las ganancias de sus ventas como televisor, DVD, equipo de sonido. Hubo un momento que debido a los inesperados desastres naturales provocó un huayco en la zona que dificultó el transito por tres día a los camiones (compradores mayoristas) teniendo que rematar la mercadería de tubérculos a fin de recuperar algo de la inversión. El crédito que necesita es para comprar la semilla, abono, hacer instalaciones de alfalfa, contratar a peones para el arado y riego de la tierra. Trabajar así permite no faltar en la economía para su hogar.
texts.en:
UNION COLLANA This communal bank is made up of eleven micro-entrepreneurs, most of whom are farmers. The members manage to support their families through their businesses, and one of their many goals is to provide the best for their families. Let’s hear the testimony of Adrían, who has been the group’s treasurer for more than two-and-a-half years. He has been a farmer for over ten years. His parents gave him some land that he uses to plant alfalfa—this is the crop that he produces the most and gets the most return from, since it is harvested six times a year. Like all parents, he wants to provide the best for his two children, aged 11 and 6 years old. He also grows fruits such as apples and quinces along with other crops that include corn, peas, spinach, and potatoes. He needed a loan in order to purchase seeds, fertilizer, pesticides, and herbicides. He sells his produce to wholesale buyers from the market. Adrían and his wife share the expenses of educating their children and providing them with clothes and food. They have even purchased some electrical appliances that they didn’t have before when they didn’t earn profits from their sales, such as a TV, a DVD player, and audio equipment. There was a period when the region was hit by unexpected natural disasters in the wake of a flash flood, which made transport difficult—the journey (for the wholesale buyers) took three days by truck—and Adrían had to sell off his produce to make up for some of the investment. The loan that he needs now is for purchasing seeds and fertilizer for planting alfalfa, and hiring farm workers to plow and irrigate the land. Working thus allows him to earn money for his family.

Translated from Spanish by Christopher Knutson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and fertilizer for planting alfalfa

loans.name: Luz Y Progreso Group

texts.es:
LUZ Y PROGRESO

Este grupo de once personas se dedican al comercio minorista, por diferentes circunstancias tuvieron que buscar la manera de generar sus propios ingresos a través de sus negocios con el propósito de no faltar la economía en sus hogares.
Doris tienes 36 años, es madre de tres niños aún menores de edad (15,13,5 años). A los 29 años tuvo la iniciativa de preparar en casa comida típica de la sierra (sopa de trigo, tallarines con chanfainita, picante de trigo, chuño, yuyo) así iba con su canasta y ollas a ofrecer su comida a los vendedores y a los que transitaban en los mercados; estuvo así regular tiempo sus ventas eran muy buenas debido que no era frecuente encontrar este tipo de comida y a la mayoría de los comerciantes les agrada. Los ingresos de estas ventas solventaron los gastos de alimentación, educación en los momentos en que su esposo no contaba con trabajo. Posteriormente dejó de vender así porque tenía que dar los debido cuidados a su último hijo, pero no fue impedimento para empezar a vender abarrotes en su casa con el capital que ahorró de su anterior negocio compró: 1 saco de arroz, 1 ½ de azúcar, 1 Doc.leche, 1 Doc.atún, sal y detergentes. Los préstamos que recibió lo utilizó para implementar más su negocio y generar más ingresos que le permitiera comprar los útiles de colegio a sus hijos, matricularlos, de igual modo mejorar su casa, instaló un tanque para el agua potable, hizo una ventana de fierro. Este negocio paga los gastos familiares, ya que el sueldo de su pareja no es lo suficiente y Doris quiere para sus niños una mejor calidad de vida, terminar de construir su vivienda. El préstamo que obtendrá será para la compra de dulces, leche, aceite, papel higiénico, atún, gaseosas. 

Juana tiene 47 años, madre de dos hijos. El negocio al que se dedica es la venta de pescado, ayuda a su madre en su puesto; para ello se levanta muy temprano 5:30 para comprar la mercadería que necesita en el terminal de Villa María (Lima) esto lo hace por lo menos tres veces por semana compra cuarenta a veinte kilos entre : bonito, jurel, mariscos, pejerrey, tollo, perico, sierra lo que se conoce como doble o simple. Los ingresos de este negocio es para ayudar a su esposo con los gastos de su hogar.
El préstamo es para comprar bonito y jurel que son pescados de mayor demanda por los consumidores.
texts.en:
The group "Luz y Progreso" is made up of 11 people who work in various segments of retail trade. They had to look for a way to generate their own incomes through their businesses, with the objective supporting their households economically. Doris is 36 years old, and is the mother of three children aged 15, 13 and 5. When she was 29 she took the initiative to start preparing meals typical of the sierra region (wheat soup, noodles, spicy wheat, dried potatoes, yuyo); she took them in baskets and pots out to sell in the markets to the vendors and people passing through. She was there for a fair amount of time and her sales were very good; the traders liked her food as this type of meal was not generally available. The income from these sales paid for her food expenses, and for her children's education at the time when her husband did not have a job. Later, she stopped selling because she had to care for her last child, but this did not stop her from beginning to sell groceries from the house. With money that she saved from her previous work she bought: a sack of rice, 1 1/2 sacks of sugar, a dozen units of milk and tuna, salt and detergent. Loans that she received in the past enabled her to set up her business and generate more income so that she was be able to buy school supplies for her children and enroll them in school. In addition she improved her home, installing a tank of potable water and putting in an iron window. This business pays for her family's expenses, given that the salary of her partner is not sufficient to cover them. Doris wants a better quality of life for her children and to finish construction on her home. With this loan she will buy sweets, milk, cooking oil, toilet paper, tuna and soft drinks. Juana is 47 years old and is the mother of 2 children. She and her partner have a business selling fish from a stand. To do this she gets up very early at 5:30am to buy the merchandise that she needs at the fishing terminal Villa María in Lima. She does this at least 3 times a week, buying from 20 to 40 kilos of bonito, mackerel, swordfish, parrot fish, and other fish. The income from this business helps her husband with the household expenses. This loan will be used to buy bonito and mackerel, which are the types of fish that are most in demand by her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy supplies: groceries and fish

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a young Palestinian man, age 27, who is married with two children.

Ahmad owns a barber shop where he cuts hair, shaves beards and sells creams. The salon is the only source of income for the family.

Ahmad’s shop needs new decor, especially the door, since the people outside can see the customers inside. Also, during winter the wind comes through the door as it is not well fitted which makes many customers complain.

Ahmad requested 1,500 USD to do these renovations. He appears in the photo at his salon with one of his customers.

loans.use: To pay for new decor for his salon and a new door

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Taraji

texts.en:
Taraji is a young Palestinian woman, 30 years old. She is married with four children who are still at school.

Taraji started her business two years ago with the help of her husband to increase their income. Her husband works as a police officer and his salary is not enough for a family of six members, especially when everything in Gaza is getting more expensive due to the constraints. In addition, the family went through a tough time when the government salaries were stopped for more than a year in 2006/2007 when the USA and the EU stopped their support of the Palestinian National Authority after the 2006 election.

Taraji and her husband buy lambs, raise them, and then sell them to butcher shops. Taraji has requested 1,000 USD from FATEN to buy more lambs. In addition to that they plan to start their own butcher shop as the profit will be even greater.

Taraji appears in the photo with her husband at the barn carrying one of the lambs.

loans.use: To purchase more lambs and to open a butcher shop

loans.name: Marlene

texts.en:
Marlene Q. is from the village of Landing. She is 39 years old. Marlene is still single. To make a living, Marlene owns & operates a dressmaking and tailoring shop. Marlene has been engaged in her business for over 16 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2002, Marlene joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP, which will be used to purchase farm inputs and labor for her rice land. This will be the 14th loan taken out by Marlene from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For purchase of farm inputs for her rice production activities.

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en:
Bernadette B. is from the village of So. Poblacion. She is 35 years old. Bernadette is married and has 1 infant child and 2 school-aged children. Bernadette owns & operates a dressmaking and a shoe repair shop. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from sewing and shoe repairs and also from fishing to local businesses and community members. Bernadette has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Bernadette joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. She is requesting a new loan of 12000 PHP, which will be used to purchase housing materials for repairs to her house. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Bernadette from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For the purchase of housing materials.

loans.name: Mujeres Solidarias 3 & 4 Group

texts.en:
Maria is the coordinator for her group, Mujeres Solidarias (Women in Solidarity). Her story is representative of her group, as well as of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in Puerto Plata, a northern city dependent on tourism for its economy and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple set-up with her long term partner and their child.

Maria is excited to be taking her second loan from Esperanza after having successfully repaid her previous loan. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling clothing and vegetables by purchasing two dozen pairs of panties, pants and two dozen t-shirts as well as three dozen vegetables. She will use the profits to invest in notebooks and books for her child. In the long term she hopes to buy a house with the earnings from her business. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: To purchase clothing and vegetables to sell

loans.name: Blass Group

texts.es:
En este año nuevo el grupo Blas integrado por Elizabeth Martínez, Rosa G. y Luisa Emilia desean seguir laborando para que sus negocios crezcan. Es por está razón que ellas desde los primeros días de este año trabajaran arduamente. 

Elizabeth Martínez es la coordinadora del grupo y comercializa cosméticos de distintas marcas. Mientras su compañera Rosa G. tiene una panadería la cual en estos días posee muchos pedidos de pan, tortas y repostería para está época por ello invertirá el préstamo en la compra de ingredientes como  leche, levadura, harina, huevo entre otros.

De la misma manera Luisa Emilia L. tiene pedidos  de carne  para este 31 de diciembre y los primeros días de enero ya que gran parte de la población realiza los típicos nacatamales para esta fecha, el relleno…etc.
texts.en:
In this new year the Blas group consisting of Elizabeth Martínez, Rosa G. and Luisa Emilia wish to continue working in order to make their businesses grow. For this reason they will work hard from the first days of this new year. Elizabeth Martínez is the coordinator of the group and she sells various brands of cosmetics. Her colleague Rosa G. has a bakery where these days she has many order of bread, cakes and desserts for this seasn and she will invest in buying ingredients such as milk, yeast, flour, egg and others. Likewise Luisa Emilia L. has order of meat for December 341 and the first days of January as many people make nacatamales (a traditional steamed corn cake) during this time period, stuffing, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cosmetics, baking ingredients, meat

loans.name: Hossana Group

texts.es: El grupo Hosana integrado por Ana A. quien tiene una pulpería, Socorro B. vende cosméticos y ropa y Patricia comercializa ropa.  Ellas desean iniciar el nuevo año con trabajo, fuerza y la esperanza de  seguir laborando para que sus negocios crezcan. Es por está razón que ellas desde los primeros días de este año trabajaran arduamente.
texts.en:
The Hosana group consists of Ana A. who has a small store, Socorro B. sells cosmetics and clothing and Patricia sells clothing. They wish to start the new year with work, strength and hope of continuing working in order to grow their businesses. For this reason they will work hard from the first days of the new year.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy basic needs items

loans.name: Gissella's Group

texts.es:
El grupo  Jazmín integrado por tres mujeres tragadoras ellas son Gissella C. quien tiene una mini tienda de  ropa usada en su casa de habitación, Elia E. trabaja con la venta de recargas, tarjetas y alquiler de llamadas y Gissel Campos tiene una pequeña pulpería.

Ellas desean iniciar el nuevo año con trabajo para que sus negocios crezcan. Es por está razón que desde los primeros días de este año trabajaran arduamente.
texts.en:
The Jazmín group consists of three women; Gissella C. has a mini-store of used clothing in her home, Elia E. works selling refillable phone cards, phone cards, and phone service and Gissell Campos has a small convenience store. They wish to start the new year with work so that their businesses grow. For this reason they will work hard from the first days of the new year.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bundles of used clothing

loans.name: Las Toruños Group

texts.es:
El grupo las T. está integrado por tres mujeres trabajadoras que invertirán el crédito en sus respectivos negocios. Una de ellas es Zeneida T. quien desde muy joven aprendió a ganarse la vida ella actualmente comercializa cosméticos de distintas marcas.

Marisol T. hace y vende nacatamales, una comida típica de Nicaragua que se come especialmente los fines de semana ya sea en la mañana, en el almuerzo o la cena. Esta señora aprendió el arte culinario y los secretos necesarios para hacer este delicioso  pecado para las personas a dieta o con colesterol de su madre quien le enseño todo.

Mientras Heyling L. tiene un pequeño restaurante popular conocido como fritanga porque la mayoría de sus alimentos son fritos. Estás son muy populares en Nicaragua y su comercio es especialmente en las noches.
texts.en:
The T. group consists of three hard working women who will invest the loan in their respective businesses. One of them is Zeneida T. who at a young age learned how to earn a living and today she sells a variety of cosmetics. Marisol T. makes and sells nacatamales (a steamed corn cake), a typical food of Nicaragua that is eaten on the weekends for breakfast, lunch, or dinner. This woman learned this culinary art and the necessary secrets to make these delicious items for people on a diet or with high cholesterol. Her mother taught her everything she knows. Meanwhile Heyling L. has a small popular restaurant known as a “friganga”(frying place) because the majority of her foods are fried. These are very popular in Nicaragua and her business is conducted in the evenings.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cosmetics

loans.name: Llegaremos A La Meta Group

texts.es:
Idalia M., Margarita O. y María Auxiliadora M. integran al grupo Llegaremos a la meta, cuyo nombre es cogiera  porque ese es su lema. Estas tres mujeres emprendedoras iniciaran este año con toda la fuerza posible.

La señora Idalia M. comenzó vendiendo cosméticos y actualmente comercializa ropa, Margarita O. vende ropa, zapatos y cosméticos y María Auxiliadora M. por la mañanas vende tortillas, en las noches fritanga y los fines de semana sopa.
texts.en:
Idalia Morán, Margarita O., and María Auxiliadora M. make up the “We Will Reach Our Goal” Group. The name is appropriate because it is their slogan. These 3 enterprising women will begin the new year with all possible effort.

Mrs. Idalia Morán began by selling cosmetics and, now, she sells clothing. Margarita O. sells clothes, shoes, and cosmetics. María Auxiliadora M. sells tortillas in the mornings, grilled food in the afternoons, and soup on weekends.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY CLOTHING TO SELL

loans.name: In Progress Group

texts.en:
This group of eight women live in Pocosi, Limon, in the hot and humid climate bordering the Caribbean coast of Costa Rica. Each group member is applying for a loan of 100,000 colons. The women partake in various revenue-generating activities such as the production and sale of homemade bread or clothing as well as the sale of catalogue items such as cosmetics and health products.

The women who sell catalogue items can earn a 20% margin for their efforts. This loan will be used to purchase inventory items as well as raw materials for clothes and bread making. It will also be used for general investments for the expansion of each woman’s business. The goals of this group are to help each other sell more products and ensure the good health of each member.

Anay is 57 years old, divorced, and has three daughters. Although she did not finish primary school, she has completed some technical courses in sewing. She has a business selling various catalogue items such as cosmetics, health products and clothing, going from door to door in her community. She started her business with an initial investment of 10,000 colons and, in a good month, she can earn 92,000 colons.

Anay plans to use the current loan for the purchase of inventory products which she will then be able to sell to her clients on credit. She mentioned that her business is growing and she hopes this loan will help her expand, offer her better deals and broaden her client base. She recognizes that the main need of her clients is good health, which her products help provide.

Yessenia sells handmade clothing to clients in her community. She is 29 years old and has completed primary school. She plans to use this loan to purchase raw materials necessary for making clothes. She says that she hopes that by joining the group, she will learn from her fellow members how to run an efficient enterprise and to make wise business investments. She describes the relationships amongst the group members as “very good” and “united”.

Yessenia’s aim is to combine this loan and the business wisdom of her colleagues in order to generate more family income. She says, “I would like to be able to give my children some treats once in a while, like ice cream.” Her goal is to increase business growth, to keep learning every day and to re-invest in her business - “to make every day better than the last.” With her faith and the group, she feels that she can achieve these goals.

loans.use: To buy more inventory

loans.name: Mai

texts.en:
Mai A. A. is FATEN’s first repeat loan on Kiva!! 

Mai is an example of Palestinian women who stand side-by-side with their husbands to help their families provide a better future for their children.

Mai is one of FATEN oldest clients who began with the start of the FATEN branch in Hebron. She took several loans and gradually increased the amounts and this is her second loan with Kiva. She previously took 2,000 USD and repaid it way ahead of the due-date as her greenhouse went very well.

Now Mai needs another 2,000 USD for land reclamation and preparing it for planting. She will plant cauliflowers and beans as this is the season for them.

Mai appears in the photo collecting her cucumber harvest at her greenhouse. This harvest was financed with the help of her first Kiva loan.

loans.use: To pay for land reclamation and preparation for planting

loans.name: Lida

texts.en:
Lida B.'s main source of income comes from raising hogs to sell in her community. Lida is a 33-year-old married woman from the village of Minlasag. Lida has been in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2007, Lida joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Lida has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Lida is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase feed, medicine and additional hogs. This will be her 5th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Chanthavy

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthavy T. (pictured here), 38, and her husband, Mr. Vichet Meas, 42, were married in 1992 and have four children: three sons and one daughter. The family lives along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. 

Chanthavy and her husband are farmers. They grow jasmine flowers on their farmland. Besides farming, they also sell jasmine flowers at the market in Phnom Penh. Some they buy from farmers in the village for resale; some are from their own farm. 

Chanthavy is requesting a loan in the amount of $1,000 to purchase jasmine flowers from farmers on contract. She needs to pay money to the farmers first, before the harvest season. She also will use a part of her loan to buy a pesticide applicator to use on her jasmine-flower farm.

loans.use: To purchase jasmine flowers from farmers under contract for resale and to buy a pesticide applicator

loans.name: Mama

texts.en:
Mama is 59 and married with 8 children.  She owns & operates a business venture, planting & harvesting bananas for sale.  She has 2 years of experience in this business.    Mama needs a loan of WST $1500 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 40 talas or US $17 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Mama joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Mama's 2nd loan with SPBD. 

Overall Social Metric Score:*               1 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              1 out of 3

*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers.  Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the ""overall social metric score.""  For example, a 3 out of 3 on ""level of education"" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university. "

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. 

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Alofa

texts.en:
Alofa F. is 62 and married with 8 children (ages 22 - 40).  She owns a business venture, selling both food & daily use products in the local community.  Alofa has 7 years of experience in this business.  Alofa needs a loan of WST $2500 to purchase additional products to sell.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 700 talas or US $292 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2007, Alofa joined SPBD.    This is her 4th loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Alofa's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

Overall Social Metric Score:*                1.87 out of 3
Level of Education:                              2 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              1 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress.  The overall social metric score is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation.  A higher number represents a higher score.  For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.  

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15"

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD : http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

Pasikalia is 34 and married with 7 children.  She owns & operates a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  She has 3 years of experience in this business.    Pasikalia needs a loan of WST $2700 to purchase harvesting equipment such as wheelbarrows, shovels, rakes, baskets, and knives.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 35 talas or US $15 per week) to make improvements to her house.

Level of total Household Income:         1 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              1 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. loans.name: Wahida Ziba Group

texts.en:
This is the Wahida Ziba group, which is made up of four members. These four members have requested a group loan of 40,000 Afghani.  

Wahida is the group leader. She is married and has eight children: four sons and four daughters. She runs an embroidery business in her home. She has two years of experience in this business. Wahida wants to buy some necessary things for her embroidery business. 

Zakia, another member, has a tailoring business and with this loan, wants to buy more clothes for tailoring. Through her income, she supports her family members and her purpose of getting a loan is to expand her business. 

The third member, Frishta, wants to take a loan for her husband, who has a car-parts shop. With this loan, Frishta’s husband wants to expand his business.

The last member is Ziba, who wants to take a loan for her son. He also wants to buy some good materials for his car-parts shop and wants to start his business in a new way to support all of his family members.
 
They all would like to thank the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy items for her embroidery business

loans.name: Barbara

texts.en: Mrs. Barbara P. is from the village of D'Ban Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 49 years old. She is married and blessed with three adult children. She owns and operates a business providing manicures and pedicures in the local community. Barbara has been engaged in her business for 15 years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippines pesos a month for these activities. In 2003, Barbara joined PMPC, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Barbara has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional materials to use. Barabara is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the third loan taken out by Barbara from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English

loans.use: Purchase materials for her existing business

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en: Carmelita R., pictured with her two grandkids, is from the village of Clarin, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 48 years old. Carmelita is married and has one adult child. To make a living, Carmelita raises livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Carmelita has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 6,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Carmelita joined GDMPC, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmelita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. Carmelita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. This will be the second loan taken out by Carmelita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.name: Chanthun

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthun H., 31, and her husband, Mr. Chen Chum, 32, live about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have two children, one son and one daughter. Both are still young. 

Chanthun has been a scarf weaver for more than three years. She sells her finished products at a market in Phnom Penh. Her husband works in a garment factory. 

Chanthun has asked for a loan from Kiva through Maxima one time already. She now is requesting another loan of $700 to purchase cotton thread to continue her scarf-weaving business.

loans.name: Sophak

texts.en:
Mr. Sophak S., age 34, and his wife, Mrs. Sophea Lok (pictured together), age 29, have been married since 1999. They have three children: a son and two daughters. The family is living approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Sophak has been a farmer for three years. He grows corn and eggplant on his own farmland. His wife works for a NGO. He doesn’t have enough capital to use on his farm, so he is applying for his first loan of $1,000 in order to purchase fertilizer, pesticides, seeds and a water pump.

loans.use: To purchase farming supplies.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita M. is from the village of Misom, Baliangao Mis. Occ. She is 49 years-old. Carmelita is married and one adult child. Carmelita owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as coconut vinegar, coffee, shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Carmelita has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Carmelita joined Kiva partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carmelita is requesting a first loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Baby Jane

texts.en:
Mrs. Baby Jane C. is a direct seller of Avon Products, Fullerlife Products, DXN Food Supplement Products, longganisa and chorizo (Filipino local sausages). She is 42 years-old and a resident of Purok 4- Maquilao in Tangub City. She has two children, aged 12 and 17 and her husband is a construction worker in Cagayan de Oro city. Four years ago, when Baby Jane realized that her husband's income was not enough to support the entire family, particularly with the cost of the children's education, she opened her store.

She now earns an average net income of not less than PHP 4,000.00. Baby Jane has been a member of Kiva partner Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperation (PMPC) for two years. She plans to take out an eight loan of PHP 5,000 to add a new line of goods to her general store: dried fish which is a popular snack in the Philippines. The future income from this loan will be used to pay for her weekly obligations and savings for her children's future.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

texts.en:
Isaack is 34 years-old and married. He is blessed with three children. Isaack is a shopkeeper and he started his business one year ago.

Isaack was introduced to Kadet by an existing client. This will be his first loan with Kadet and he plans to add stock such as cooking oil, maize flour, bathing soap and other household items. He has never borrowed from any other MFI before.

Isaack earns a profit of Kshs 40,000 per month and he intends to put his profits back into business. By doing so he hopes the business will grow and one day he will be operating a wholesale shop.

texts.en:
Mercy is a single mother aged 34 years old. She has one daughter named Grace who is 12 years old. Mercy has been operating a tailoring and dress making business for the past four years. She also supplies polythene paper and rice to schools within the area.

She was introduced to Kadet through an existing Kadet client and she plans to purchase more stock like polythene paper and rice for supplies. She also intends to expand her tailoring business with the extra profit generated from the supply business.

Mercy is a single mother and is educating her daughter with the income she makes from her business. She also loves to sing and is in the process of recording gospel music. Her hopes and dreams are to be a polythene paper distributor and to join the music industry. Mercy describes herself as a hardworking lady, a visionary and a risk taker.

loans.use: To purchase more supplies and expand her tailoring business.

loans.name: Kimlun

texts.en:
Mrs. Kimlun N., 50, and her husband, Mr. Sarun Yoy, 53, have been married since 1981 and have three sons and two daughters. Three of them have full-time employment and other daughter attends University. The family lives in a small village along national road number 4 about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Kimlun has been selling medicine in front of her house for two months. Her husband has been a motor taxi driver since 1990. The couple hopes to support their daughter's further education so that she will get a good job when she finishes her studies.

Hence, Kimlun is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to pay for school fees for her daughter.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her daughter.
